title: Olivia Newton-John on why social media has made life difficult for women
text:
She is one of Australia's most famous exports, having sold millions of records and starred in iconic '70s musical Grease.

And Olivia Newton-John has spoken about the challenges younger women face these days that she didn't encounter while growing up in Australia in the '60s.

In an interview with The Australian Women's Weekly, the 71-year-old said: 'I think it's tough for the young ones, because they're trying to keep up with those images of perfection [on social media] that aren't real.'

'They're trying to keep up with images that aren't real': Olivia Newton-John (pictured) says it's 'tough' for young women these days who want to look perfect on social media

Olivia's daughter, singer and actress Chloe Lattanzi, 33, agreed with her mother and also alluded to her own struggles with anorexia and body dysmorphia.

She said: 'It's the inside stuff that matters. It's the inner work. That's what social media never talks about. People are celebrated for how much money they make or what they look like.

'I want to use my minor celebrity to remind people they are amazing inside. I was suffering [from anxiety and anorexia] and I only healed when I realised all that stuff inside me is what's amazing. Not the outside. I was fixated on the outside.'

Health battles: Olivia's daughter, singer and actress Chloe Lattanzi (left), was once a prolific social media user and previously struggled with anorexia and body dysmorphia

Chloe, who was once a prolific social media user, struggled with body dysmorphia and anorexia in her teenage years, and at one stage weighed just 37kg.

In 2013, she underwent treatment at a rehab clinic to battle her addiction issues and depression.

Speaking to 60 Minutes in August, Chloe said she had been forced to put her own problems aside to help her mother, who is battling cancer.

Struggles: Chloe struggled with body dysmorphia and anorexia in her teenage years, and at one stage weighed just 37kg. Pictured with her mother in Los Angeles on January 24, 2004

'I wanted to be bright and happy and available for my mum when she was struggling with this and I thought I was okay but I wasn't, I was still struggling with severe depression and I faced it head on,' she said.

'There's no more running away from your pain. Deal with it, she needs you. I feel it's made me a much better person.'

Olivia was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2017. She had previously battled the disease twice before, in 1992 and 2013.
